Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Addressing the Technical Security Challenges of Emerging Digital Financial Services

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
While wealthier individuals throughout the world have access to cashless payment systems (e.g., credit and debit cards) that are managed by a secured and insured financial infrastructure (e.g., banks and other financial institutions), many of the world's poor lack banking or credit accounts. Emerging digital financial services are now offered as "mobile money apps" by companies operating in various countries and are widely used. Unfortunately, the researchers have found that the cybersecurity protections provided by many of these apps are far weaker than those provided by the traditional financial institutions. Thus, many of the world's poorest people unknowingly risk their money by using badly protected mobile money apps. This workshop brings together cybersecurity experts from academia and industry, as well as government policy makers and representatives from non-governmental organizations. The participants will develop and document specific technical recommendations for mobile money app security properties.

Cybersecurity researchers, students and engineers have expressed their interest in working to improve cybersecurity for emerging digital financial services. By developing and documenting specific technical recommendations for mobile money app security, this workshop will provide guidance on concrete actions that can be taken by the research and development communities. While identifying technology approaches to improving cybersecurity in mobile money apps, the workshop will encourage new cross-disciplinary collaboration among participants, as they work together to address this challenging problem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this award was to hold a workshop (in Washington, DC) that would bring together academic security experts, entrepreneurs, authorities on policy, and a range of other officials to created a concerted effort to improve the security in emerging mobile banking and micro-investing.

Due to a combination of a number of factors (e.g., specifically the natural movement of contacts in the non-profit space, COVID-induced staffing reductions in non-profits, the inability to travel domestically or internationally), we were unable to hold this workshop as intended. Accordingly, while significant effort went into the planning/organization of this event, the overwhelming majority of funds are being returned to the NSF).

We note that in spite of the workshop not occurring, this effort did produce positive results. Specifically, one Ph.D. student (African-American female) was able to use the planning/organization efforts to extend her network of contacts, and to ask a range of regulators, subject-matter experts (e.g., bankers, merchants, etc), and public policy authorities important questions that resulted directly in results in her dissertation. She finished her Ph.D. in Summer of 2020 and is now working as a full time research engineer in a US-based FFRDC (performing work based on the skills developed partially by this project). Another Ph.D. student (US female) used to contacts developed through this effort to become involved in a security analysis of a central African mobile money environment, gaining valuable skills in the use of real-world technical tools and security assessment

Additionally, the process of organizing this event created many new contacts, which we hope will lead to future domestic and international collaborations on how the world's most financially vulnerable can be best protected in the emerging world of mobile money and micro-investing.
